content.description:
An alpine style adventure with an absolutely wild bolted mixed roof pitch less than an hour from the car. What more could you want? P1 50m: Head up the thin (or nonexistant) lower angle ice passing an occasional fixed pin or bolt if you can find them to a 2 bolt anchor below a low angle broken corner. P2 20m: Either go left from the belay onto rolling ice to a 2 bolt belay on the right where a small curtain of ice forms, or mixed climb up the broken corner following a few bolts to the same anchor. P3 50m: Head straight up increasingly steepening ice to a massive platform belay with a two bolt anchor. P4 20m: The crux pitch. Follow 11 bolts through a wild roof traverse of M7+ mixed climbing. As soon as you are able to transfer to the ice after the last bolt should be a belay cave with a 2 bolt anchor. If the ice has closed up this cave continue up on the ice until you are able to build an anchor. P5 35m: Move out of the belay cave and straight up for steep WI5 ice that is likely sun rotted in sections. Belay off a tree at the top. Descent: 3 rappels on 70m ropes gets you to the bottom. Top of P5 to top of P3. Top of P3 to top of P1, then to the ground. Tie your knots as the second rappel is almost the full 70. Note that you MAY be able to climb from P1 anchors straight to the top of P3 with 70m of rope, however the leader would need to know exactly where the anchor is and not meander unnecessarily. Approach as for Essondale by dropping down onto the train tracks heading East until you are past an obvious giant grey boulder immediately beside the tracks. If you make it to the train signal you've gone about a hundred meters too far.

Just past the boulder go straight up the gully until you are directly below the climb, a single belay bolt marks the start of the first pitch. An hour from the car. Standard ice rack, 11 quickdraws, and some pins may be useful for P1 if ice is thin or nonexistent.

Another Kicking Horse Canyon classic, Essondale Right follow the ice that can be seen up higher on the cliffs from the highway. P1: Climb a steep WI4 ~12 meter curtain followed by about 35 meters of snow ledge/very low angle ice that gets you to the base of the P2 pillar. Build a belay on the left, or alternatively head up another 10 meters and build a sheltered belay behind the pillar on the right. P2: Fire straight up the steep crux pillar to more mellow terrain, build a belay. P3: Climb up the final 60 meters of rolling WI4 ice to a tree anchor. Rappel the route. From the parking walk along the highway until you are on the West side of the Highway bridge crossing the river. Walk under the bridge and down to the railroad tracks, heading East along the tracks for about 300 meters.

Once you pass a grey power box on the south side of the rails look up and to the left, you should see the climb. Grovel your way up the gully to the base. Be aware a direct line straight up the gully containing the climb isn't possible as you will get cliffed out, so you need to traverse in from either side slightly about 2/3rds of the way up the gully.

About 10 meters of approach ice will get you to the base of the pitch 1 curtain, with a good belay tree on the left.

About 45 minutes - hour depending on route finding and conditions Standard ice rack.

A Kicking Horse canyon classic with a short approach. Pitch 1 - 40 meters, WI3: Climb up through the notch to a bolted anchor on the right on the big snow ledge separating the pitches. Pitch 2 - 40 meters, WI3-4: Climb steeper ice to a tree anchor on the right. Descent - One rappel on double 70m ropes will get you straight to the ground, double 60s won't make it. Legally park at the parking lot by the Inukshuk at 51.30479237961376, -116.8911811164198 and walk 1.2km up the highway towards the gully containing the route at 51.306737101538204, -116.87451352065332

Walk up the narrow gully scrambling up past a boulder and then either go up the approach ice on the right fork of the gully or walk left and traverse in back right up high to the base of the climb. Standard Ice Rack

The most apparent and easily accessible of the roadside Kicking Horse Canyon climbs, Pretty Nuts is a class that always forms.

Just past the bridge 2.6km away from the Kicking Horse Rest Area is the first pitch on the right, 50 meters from the highway shoulder.

P1: Climb a rope stretching 70 meters of WI3-4 ice to a tree belay.

P2: Trudge up 20 meters of snow to another tree anchor on the left, belay here and climb up 10 meters of steep WI4 curtain to mellow WI2 ice for another 30 meters to a tree belay on the right.

P3: Hike 80 meters directly to the right from the P2 tree anchor across 2 drainages to the obvious final 40 meter pitch of ice with multiple possible lines.

Rappel the route.

Immediately on the right side of the road past the bridge that's 2.6km West of Kicking Horse Rest Area.
Standard ice rack.
Located along Hwy 1 starting about 10km past the town of Golden and going along the highway up until the Park Bridge, Kicking Horse Canyon is host to a number of classic roadside ice climbs.
